HOPPER HOUSE ART

Twenty-five distinguished artists have lent works to an exhibition celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Hopper House Art Center in Nyack. It opens today with a reception from noon to 4:30 P.M., and will continue through Dec. 1.

The title of the exhibition, ''Realism after 7 A.M.: Realist Painting After Edward Hopper,'' was taken from his painting ''7 A.M.,'' which is believed to have been inspired by a storefront on North Broadway and School Street in Upper Nyack.

Represented in the show are Eric Fischl, Alex Katz, Malcolm Morley, Philip Pearlstein, Fairfield Porter, Ed Ruscha, Mark Tansey and John Beerman. The curator was the New York art critic Richard Milazzo, who will give a talk at the gallery on Friday at 7 P.M.

The center, converted from Hopper's boyhood home and maintained by the nonprofit Edward Hopper Landmark Preservation Foundation, is at 82 North Broadway. Hours are Thursday through Sunday from noon to 5 P.M., and Friday evening until 7:30. Admission is free but a donation of $1 is suggested. For more information, call 358-0774.
THE OTHER HOLMES

''Harley Holmes,'' Joe Hartin's comedy about Sherlock's envious sibling, will open at the Paramount East in Peekskill on Saturday at 8 P.M. Produced by the Theater Arts Guild of Peekskill, the seven-character play was first presented at a drama festival in Dayton, Ohio, in 1995, and had a four-week run last July Off Broadway at the Harold Clurman Theater in Manhattan.

The script revolves around Harley's attempts to match his brother's fame by hiring a writer to record his (Harley's) adventures as a detective, mimicking Dr. Watson's chronicles of Sherlock's capers. He is convinced that it was Dr. Watson's way with words that created Sherlock's reputation rather than Sherlock's deeds. Of course he comes up short.

After opening night, performances are scheduled on Nov. 7, 8 and 9 at 8 P.M., with matinees next Sunday and Nov. 10 at 2 P.M. The theater is at 1016 Brown Street, and tickets at $8 to $12 can ay be reserved by calling 736-6729.
TELLING STORIES

Jonathan Kruk, Westchester's intrepid storyteller, pays homage to the spooky season today at 1 P.M. with an hourlong family program of tales steeped in mystery and history. It will take place at the John Jay Homestead, 400 Route 22 in Katonah, and admission will be $5, $4 for people 65 and older, and $3 for children. Complimentary cookies and cider will be served at the close of Mr. Kruk's presentation, and free guided tours of the homestead will be available.

Real and imagined characters are woven into Mr. Kruk's stories of Major Andre's ghost and the spirit of the White Lady of Tarrytown who died of a broken heart when her Tory lover abandoned her. The Revolutionary War hero Luther Kennecott who spied on the British; Enoch Cosby, who worked to defend the Hudson Valley, and John Jay himself, who was involved in uncovering those who were plotting against the patriots, are some of the characters populating the stories. For directions, reservations or more information, call 232-5651.
WOMEN'S SERIES

The new Women's Center established in Founder's Hall on the Manhattanville College campus in Purchase offers its first series of programs aimed at women of all ages and life styles. Five free workshops will be presented from tomorrow through January, and two three-part seminars are scheduled at a cost of $25 each.

Established by the college and Westchester Jewish Community Services, one of the county's largest nonprofit, nonsectarian health and social services agencies, the new center will maintain a drop-in area, a resource for referrals to specific services, and a venue for counseling, workshops and seminars.

Tomorrow from 6 to 8:30 P.M. the first free workshop will address the topic of careers and decision making and include a screening of the film ''My Brilliant Career.'' Adult children and aging parents will be the subject on Nov. 6 from 1 to 2:30 P.M. On Nov. 20 from noon to 1:30 P.M., the discussion will focus on balancing work and family. The sessions on Nov. 21 and Jan. 22 from 10 to 11:30 A.M. will cover roles and relationships, and communications skills within the family, respectively.

The seminars, on Nov. 12, 19 and 16, and Nov.18, 25 and Dec. 2, will be held from 9:30 to 11 A.M. The first one will be about the impact of physical, sexual and emotional abuse on adult women; the second will explore self-esteem and inner resources.
For more information or to sign up for a program, call one of the co-directors: Lenore Rosenbaum, 949-0788, extension 237, or Dr. Nancy Harris, 323-5330.
ARTISTS AT NARDIN

The Nardin Galleries in Somers is exhibiting the unusual work of two artists: Leo Manso, a collagist whose pieces are small in scale, beautifully colored and subtly composed; and William King, a sculptor who uses nontraditional materials and a tongue-in-cheek approach to his subjects.
The show will be on view through Nov. 17, Tuesdays through Sundays from noon to 7 P.M. or by appointment. The Nardin Galleries are on Route 202 and the phone number is 276-8485.
GARDEN PARADE

Ralph Lee, a puppet and mask designer who was one of the creators of the Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, will supply a 10-foot-tall spider, tap-dancing skeletons, wizards, human-size walking pumpkin, ghosts and seasonal goblins of many kinds today from 2 to 4 P.M. when the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx holds its Halloween Parade.

Children are invited to come in costume and join the puppets perched in trees, peering from behind rocks and slinking along the colorful autumn pathways of Haunted Walk. Admission will be $1 plus grounds admission of $3; $1 for adults 65 and older, students, and children 6 through 16; free younger than 6.

Mr. Lee was the recipient of a 1996 Governor's Award for contributions to the artistic life of the state. He and his wife, Casey Compton, direct the Mettawee Theater Company, which bases its shows on myths and legends from around the world. Call (718) 817-8700 for directions or more information.
ROBERT KLEIN READING

The actor Robert Klein will turn his comedic and dramatic talents to the reading of Halloween stories for the benefit of the Hudson Valley Writer's Center today at 7 P.M. His performance, the third yearly appearance he has made for the center, will take place at the Tarrytown Music Hall and is suitable for families with children 7 and older.

The nonprofit center, headquartered in North Tarrytown, holds public readings by established and emerging writers, writing workshops for the public, special programs for disadvantaged children and battered women, and it produces small press publications of the work of new poets.
Tickets for tonight's show are $15 and $12 for children and adults older than 62. They may be bought at the box office or call 332-5953 for more information.
RELIGIOUS WORKSHOP

The 15th National Workshop on Christian-Jewish Relations begins a series of dialogues, workshops and specials events from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. today through Tuesday and from 9 to noon on Wednesday at the Sheraton Hotel in Stamford. Under the title, ''Seeking God: The Challenge of Being Religious in America,'' more than 1,000 clergy members, scholars, archivists, historians, theologians, and others from throughout the United States, Canada and from Israel, Italy and Germany, will take part as speakers, panelists and workshop leaders. The event is open to the public at $30 a day.

Karen Armstrong will deliver the keynote address on ''The Use and Abuse of Religion'' tonight at 8. A prominent commentator on religious affairs in England, she is the author of the best seller, ''A History of God; Jerusalem: One City, Three Faiths,'' and she teaches at Leo Baeck College for the Study of Judaism and Training of Rabbis in London.

Among other speakers are Mary C. Boys, professor of practical theology at the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan; Stephen L. Carter, law professor at Yale; Julius Lester, professor of Judaic and Near Eastern Studies at the University of Massachusetts; David Saperstein, who teaches First Amendment church-state law at Georgetown University, and Krister Stendahl, professor emeritus of divinity at Harvard.

Issues to be explored during the conference include black-Jewish relations, the religious right, church-state separation, creating mutual respect in the schools, women's issues, Islam in America, H.I.V., intermarriage and aspects of the Holocaust. For more information or to register, call (203) 324-7816.
